Decalage and strict fixed points

Jul 8, 2020

In this post, I would like to note some relationships between the decalage functor and strict fixed points. Let me begin by reviewing some definitions from here. A Dieudonne complex is a cochain complex and a map of graded abelian groups such that . A Dieudonne complex is said to be saturated if is -torsion-free in each degree, and is an isomorphism. For a saturated Dieudonne complex, one can construct a Verschiebung , and this allows us to define a complex ; taking the inverse limit produces a complex which we can denote (it is denoted in the linked paper). There is a canonical map , and the Dieudonne complex is said to be strict if it is saturated, and this map is a quasi-isomorphism. Finally, one can define the notion of a Dieudonne algebra: this is a commutative algebra object in the category of Dieudonne complexes which is connective, satisfies for in odd degree, and .

There is an interesting functor defined on -torsion-free complexes, defined as follows. Let denote the subcomplex of given by

This can be understood also via the Beilinson t-structure. Namely, is the complex underlying , where is the filtered -module whose th piece is the ideal . Suppose is a Dieudonne complex; then, there is a canonical map , given on degree by . In fact, if is a complex, then a map defines a Frobenius (via for ). The Dieudonne complex is saturated iff is an isomorphism.

The description via the Beilinson t-structure makes it clear that lifts to the derived category , and in turn restricts to an endofunctor on the derived category of -complete objects of (which means objects such that the degree map on is an equivalence).

Since a Dieudonne complex is saturated iff is an isomorphism, there is a equivalence from saturated Dieudonne complexes to the fixed points of on -torsion-free chain complexes. Theorem 7.3.4 of the above paper shows that, in fact, this restricts to an equivalence between strict Dieudonne complexes and the fixed points of on , i.e., .

An explicit description of the inverse functor is described here. Namely, if , so there is an equivalence . Then, let denote the complex given by , where the differential is given by the Bockstein. There is an obvious map , and multiplication by gives a map . There is also a map , defined as follows. There is a quasi-isomorphism . Suppose that is such that is divisible by , so . Then, gives a cocycle in , and so defines a cohomology class . Finally, we define . Taking the inverse limit of the maps defines .

There is a homotopical analogue of this entire story, which appears in here. Let us now give a brief resume of Antieau-Nikolaus. Recall that, following Nikolaus-Scholze, a -typical cyclotomic spectrum is an -spectrum along with an -equivariant map , with given the -action. One of the main results of Nikolaus-Scholze is that this agrees with the older/classical definition of cyclotomic spectra: these were defined as the fixed points of the genuine -fixed points functor on genuine -spectra .

Given such a spectrum, we can form , which can be defined inductively:

There is an obvious restriction map , and we can take the inverse limit of this diagram: this defines . Note that, by construction, . It is a little painful to write it out on the blog platform, but there are maps

which are the Verschiebung and Frobenius, respectively. So is a -typical topological Cartier module (we discussed this a bit last time). Given a (-typical) topological Cartier module , we can consider the cofiber . One can see, by drawing some diagrams, that this is actually a (-typical) cyclotomic spectrum. Moreover, there is a canonical map , which is an equivalence iff is an equivalence, which happens if is bounded below. We therefore have functors

Antieau-Nikolaus show that the functor is left adjoint to .

If is a stable -category with t-structure, we let denote the subcategory of bounded below objects. A topological Cartier module is said to be -complete if the inverse limit of the diagram defined by the maps is contractible. Then, the functor is fully faithful, with essential image given by the bounded below -complete topological Cartier modules.

Just like there is a definition of genuine cyclotomic spectra (which is equivalent to the Nikolaus-Scholze definition of cyclotomic spectra), there is also a definition of genuine topological Cartier modules, given by , i.e., the fixed points for on genuine -spectra. There is an equivalence .

The maxim of this post is that this equivalence is exactly like the equivalence . First, let us make some observations. The discussion in Section 3.5 of Antieau-Nikolaus shows that if is a topological Cartier module, then is a Cartier complex (we discussed some of this last time). If we further ask that be a -module in topological Cartier modules, then is actually a Dieudonne complex. It is not necessarily strict, of course. But if is a -complete bounded below topological Cartier module, then its homotopy groups are derived -complete as Cartier modules (3.28 in Antieau-Nikolaus), and hence is a -complete Cartier complex (by 3.39 in Antieau-Nikolaus). So, the map is an equivalence. Therefore is strict iff it is saturated, i.e., iff

This is not necessarily the case for a general topological Cartier module . But if is for a smooth -algebra , then is bounded below and -complete, and as Cartier complexes. Then Equation I.3.21.1.5 from here shows that is saturated, hence strict.

Next, there is a functor given by sending to , where is the category of strict Dieudonne algebras. By Corollary 4.1.5 of Bhatt-Lurie-Mathew, there is a left adjoint , given by forming the “saturated de Rham-Witt complex” (which we will not define here). This is precisely the algebraic incarnation of the adjunction between and on cyclotomic spectra and topological Cartier modules.

So, there are functors (given by the differential on the homotopy groups of any -spectrum, genuine or not) and (at least for odd , because then the Hopf map is zero, and we get a genuine differential on the homotopy groups of an -spectrum). This fits into a commutative diagram that I tried to draw on this blog but failed. Basically, in the notation introduced briefly above, is like taking strict -fixed points. To write down a more precise relationship between the fixed points of and , we should ask: given a “nice” -spectrum , how does the complex relate to ? The “nice”-ness here is supposed to mirror the condition of being -torsion-free. In other words, is obtained by some sort of decalage of ?

I believe the answer is yes, and should go as follows. Suppose is -torsion-free, i.e., the map is an equivalence (of -spectra). Consider the filtered -spectrum given by

where is given by restriction of the -action via the degree map , and the map is adjoint to the composite . There is a t-structure on genuine -spectra, given by declaring that an object is connective (resp. coconnective) if is connective (resp. coconnective) for each . We can then take the connective cover in the resulting Beilinson t-structure on filtered genuine -spectra, i.e., define
